articles.headline: Trump’s Labor Pick, Andrew Puzder, Is Critic of Minimum Wage Increases
articles.snippet: Mr. Puzder, chief executive of the company behind Hardee’s and Carl’s Jr., also strongly supports repealing the Affordable Care Act.
articles.abstract: Mr. Puzder, chief executive of the company behind Hardee’s and Carl’s Jr., also strongly supports repealing the Affordable Care Act.
articles.lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump on Thursday chose Andrew F. Puzder, chief executive of the company that franchises the fast-food outlets Hardee’s and Carl’s Jr. and an outspoken critic of the worker protections enacted by the Obama administration, to be secretary of labor.

articles.headline: Once an Oil Executive, Now a Crusader Against Fossil Fuel Stocks
articles.snippet: Louis Allstadt, a retired Exxon executive, led an effort to divest a pension fund in Cooperstown, N.Y., of stock in oil, gas and coal, a plan that has ignited a furor.
articles.abstract: Louis Allstadt, a retired Exxon executive, led an effort to divest a pension fund in Cooperstown, N.Y., of stock in oil, gas and coal, a plan that has ignited a furor.
articles.lead_paragraph: The trustees of Cooperstown, N.Y., hardly expected their village (population 1,834) to emerge as a flash point in a national debate over climate change and socially responsible investing.

articles.headline: John Glenn, American Hero of the Space Age, Dies at 95
articles.snippet: Mr. Glenn was a symbol of the space age as the first American to orbit Earth, then became a national political figure representing Ohio in the Senate.
articles.abstract: Mr. Glenn was a symbol of the space age as the first American to orbit Earth, then became a national political figure representing Ohio in the Senate.
articles.lead_paragraph: John Glenn, a freckle-faced son of Ohio who was hailed as a national hero and a symbol of the space age as the first American to orbit Earth, then became a national political figure for 24 years in the Senate, died on Thursday in Columbus, Ohio. He was 95.

articles.headline: North Dakota Could Be Biggest Loser in Ruling Against Oil Pipeline
articles.snippet: Delays are costing the pipeline’s builder hundreds of millions of dollars, but the nation’s energy supply is unlikely to suffer.
articles.abstract: Delays are costing the pipeline’s builder hundreds of millions of dollars, but the nation’s energy supply is unlikely to suffer.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Energy Transfer Partners, a major pipeline operator, has lost hundreds of millions of dollars from delays in the completion of the Dakota Access Pipeline. And its standoff with the Standing Rock Sioux Tribe over a section running through tribal lands could mean an additional $80 million a month in losses.

articles.headline: Clean Energy ‘Moving Forward’ Despite Trump’s E.P.A. Pick, Experts Say
articles.snippet: Donald J. Trump’s choice of a climate-change denier won’t undo all of the nation’s efforts to shift from coal and oil, scientists and industry experts say.
articles.abstract: Donald J. Trump’s choice of a climate-change denier won’t undo all of the nation’s efforts to shift from coal and oil, scientists and industry experts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Donald J. Trump’s choice of a fossil-fuel advocate and climate-change denier to head the Environmental Protection Agency comes at a moment when the American energy market has already shifted away from the most polluting fossil fuels, driven more by investors and economics than by federal regulations.

articles.headline: Trump as Cyberbully in Chief? Twitter Attack on Union Boss Draws Fire
articles.snippet: Donald J. Trump’s Twitter attacks on a leader of a blue-collar union local have raised concerns about how the president-elect will behave after he takes office.
articles.abstract: Donald J. Trump’s Twitter attacks on a leader of a blue-collar union local have raised concerns about how the president-elect will behave after he takes office.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Thirty years as a union boss in Indiana have given Chuck Jones a thick skin. But even threats to shoot him or burn his house down did not quite prepare him for becoming the target of a verbal takedown by the next president of the United States.

articles.headline: South Korea Enters Period of Uncertainty With President’s Impeachment
articles.snippet: A slowing economy, a growing nuclear threat from North Korea and a more assertive China are some of the challenges facing the country.
articles.abstract: A slowing economy, a growing nuclear threat from North Korea and a more assertive China are some of the challenges facing the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — For her nearly four years in office, President Park Geun-hye of South Korea cooperated closely with the United States, particularly when it came to dealing with her volatile neighbor, North Korea.

articles.headline: Foes of Russia Say Child Pornography Is Planted to Ruin Them
articles.snippet: A K.G.B. dirty trick known as “kompromat,” the fabrication of compromising or illegal material, may have returned in a particularly noxious form.
articles.abstract: A K.G.B. dirty trick known as “kompromat,” the fabrication of compromising or illegal material, may have returned in a particularly noxious form.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, England — His indomitable will steeled by a dozen years in the Soviet gulag, decades of sparring with the K.G.B. and a bout of near fatal heart disease, Vladimir K. Bukovsky, a tireless opponent of Soviet leaders and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, is not a man easily put off his stride.
